title: Synthetic Recap
body:
TORONTO (AP) — On a night where the final score was a whisper, one man’s performance was a deafening roar. Juwan Howard didn't just lead the Washington Wizards to a tense 94-92 victory over the Toronto Raptors; he authored a historic masterpiece, carrying his team across the finish line with a legendary individual display.

From the opening tip, this was the Juwan Howard Show. The Wizards' forward was unstoppable, a study in relentless efficiency. He attacked the rim with purpose, hit from mid-range with cold-blooded precision, and dominated the glass. When the final horn sounded, the stat sheet told an unbelievable story: a career-high and franchise-record 42 points, coupled with a monstrous 20 rebounds. This was not just a big game; it was a historic tour de force.

The Raptors, led by a valiant 27-point effort from Doug Christie, fought tooth and nail. They scrambled, they defended, and they refused to let the Wizards pull away. Every time Toronto threatened to seize momentum, Howard had an answer—a put-back, a turnaround jumper, a powerful post move. He was the immovable object and the irresistible force, all in one.

In the game's final, breathless moments, with the outcome hanging in the balance, it was fitting that the ball found Howard. His final points iced the game, capping a performance for the ages. He didn't just score 42; he accounted for nearly half of his team's total output, a staggering burden of responsibility shouldered with breathtaking grace and power.

The box score will forever show a two-point Wizards win. But the history books will remember this as the night Juwan Howard ascended into the record books with a 42-point, 20-rebound performance that was as iconic as it was essential.
